nodes.bodyText:
I have just now realized that we are using a GET request with a request body (containing the query params). This is commonly considered bad practice for RESTful APIs. One of the reasons being that standard HTTP infrastructure like proxies will often not consider the body of a GET request and might return a cached response which has been created for a different set of query params.
The common advice is to either use POST instead or encode the search criteria in URI query params. The latter approach is used by most GET based APIs of common services AFAIK.
Since the POST /tenantID resource is already in use we might want to consider using query params instead.
Some references:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/978061/http-get-with-request-body
https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/372664/use-case-of-http-get-request-with-a-body
Here's one which explicitly proposes a design for a search API:
https://stackoverflow.blog/2020/03/02/best-practices-for-rest-api-design/
@dejanb @ctron @calohmn WDYT?

@sophokles73 I looked up a little bit on this topic. It seems like it's generally not considered a good practice but there are exceptions like Elastic supporting it (but they also have POST alternative for environments that are challenged by this).
I could see that specifying JSON query as a GET param can be a bit messy? But it still might be a better option than introducing the whole new endpoint for search.

I agree that using GET with a query string will be preferable.
@jbtrystram we will need to update the OpenAPI spec accordingly ...

FMPOV the expected order of applying the sorting and filtering is this:

apply the filter on the set of all devices
sort the selected elements according to the sorting criteria
return the requested subset according to the paging options

Otherwise, you might get back less objects than requested, if fewer objects in the page match the filtering criteria ...

nodes.bodyText: If I am not mistaken then you are returning DeviceWithId instances to the client which include the device identifier. However, the OpenAPI spec defines the returned result as an array of Device objects which do not contain an ID.

IMHO it doesn't return all devices for a tenant. The JavaDoc from the parent class could be well reused by using {@inheritdoc} and then adding your additional comment regarding in-memory storage and paging inconsistency.
Good catch !
How about Set<String>?

pageOffset corresponds to pages and not the place holder of the result in resultset. I think here it should be int i = pageOffset*PageSize+1. Eg. When the pageSize is set to 10 and pageOffset to 2, the result should start with 21st device in the resultset and not 2nd.

IMO the offset should not be tied to the page size, they are different things. Otherwise If I want to ignore the first 5 results for whatever reason and have a page size of 10, how would I do ?
Writing this makes me realise that I should not have followed your variables names, as offset was more suited for this variable.

In the spec, it is also specified as pageOffset and not just offset. Additionally the below line is also in the description of the pageOffset.

This allows to retrieve the whole result set page by page.

AFAIK, assume that a search devices request with pageSize defined as 10 matched 100 records. By specifying offset to 0 should return the first page with 10 records. With offset 1 should retrieve the second page with next 10 records and so on. @sophokles73 WDYT?

Yes, the pageOffset contains the number of the page to retrieve. In conjunction with the pageSize (number of entries per page) you can page through the whole result set. If you want to ignore the first entries on a page, then simply retrieve the corresponding page and skip the first entries :-) This is how all APIs that I have stumbled across so far work as well ...
Ok I aligned to that.
As per the spec, if none of the devices are matched, then 404 should be returned.
